case_name: M/s. Ram Autar Lal Jain v. Bijoy Bahadur Singh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2606 of 1969 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2606 of 1969. From the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal arises from Judgment and Order dated 1st July 1968 of Patna High Court in C.W.J.C. No. 363 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: From the Judgment and Order dated the 1st July, 1968 of the Patna High Court in C. W. J. C. No. 363 of 1968.

facts.text: Ram Autar Lal Jain made application to Chhotanagpur Regional Transport Authority (RTA) for stage carriage permit on a particular route within the time fixed.

anchor.surface_text: An application made by one Ram Autar Lal Jain before the Chhotanagpur Regional Transport Authority  hereinafter referred to as the RTA  for grant of a stage carriage permit on a particular route. The application was made within the time fixed.

facts.text: Before the application could be considered, Ram Autar Lal Jain died leaving one widow and two sons as his survivors, heirs and legal representatives.

anchor.surface_text: But, before the application companyld be companysidered Ram Autar Lal Jain died leaving one widow and two sons as his survivors, heirs and legal representatives.

facts.text: Ram Autar Lal Jain's heirs formed a partnership firm called M/s. Ram Autar Lal Jain.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Autar Lal Jains heirs formed a partnership firm called M s. Ram Autar Lal Jain and an application was made before the RTA for substitution of the firm in place of Ram Autar Lal Jain deceased, the original applicant,

facts.text: Application made before RTA for substitution of the firm in place of Ram Autar Lal Jain deceased.

anchor.surface_text: an application was made before the RTA for substitution of the firm in place of Ram Autar Lal Jain deceased, the original applicant, so that the firm companyld prosecute the application before the RTA.

facts.text: RTA allowed the substitution but split up the route into two parts and granted one part to the appellant and the other part to Respondent No. 4.

anchor.surface_text: The RTA allowed the substitution but split up the route into two parts and granted one part to the appellant and the other part to the Respondent No. 4.

facts.text: Four different parties took the matter in appeal before the State Transport Authority.

anchor.surface_text: The matter did number, however, rest with the decision of the RTA but was taken up in appeal before the State Transport Authority by as many as four different parties.

facts.text: State Transport Authority set aside the order of the RTA on grounds: route could not be split up and parties failed to produce vehicle within time allowed.

anchor.surface_text: The State Transport Authority set aside the order of the RTA on various grounds, such as  i  that, the route companyld number be split up-. and  ii  that, the parties in whose favour the permit had been given bad failed to Produce the vehicle within the time allowed by the RTA.

facts.text: State Transport Authority granted the permit to Mangtulal Tulshiyan.

anchor.surface_text: The State Transport Authority granted the permit to one Mangtulal Tulshiyan.

facts.text: State Transport Authority did not go into the question of legality of substitution of the appellant firm.

anchor.surface_text: It did number go into the question of legality of substitution of the appellant firm in place of Ram Autar Lal Jain.

facts.text: Four revision petitions filed against State Transport Authority order.

anchor.surface_text: Four revision petitions having been filed against this order, the Minister companycerned remanded the case to the RTA for a reconsideration

facts.text: Minister remanded the case to RTA for reconsideration after hearing all parties which appeared before RTA on April 23, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: the Minister companycerned remanded the case to the RTA for a reconsideration after hearing all the parties which had appeared before the RTA on April 23, 1965.

facts.text: Mangtulal Tulshiyan challenged Minister's order before Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Mangtulal Tulshiyan challenged this order of the Minister before the High Court of Patna which set it aside

facts.text: Patna High Court set aside Minister's order and directed Minister to rehear only the petitioners who filed revision petitions.

anchor.surface_text: before the High Court of Patna which set it aside and directed the Minister to rehear only the petitioners who had filed revision petitions and number those who had number companyplained against the previous order before the Minister.

facts.text: Minister granted permit to Bijoy Bahadur Singh (respondent No. 4).

anchor.surface_text: The Minister, on this occasion, granted the permit in favour of Bijoy Bahadur Singh  who is respondent No. 4 in this appeal

facts.text: Minister granted permit to Bijoy Bahadur Singh on grounds he was competent, qualified, satisfied RTA requirement for new-comer and small operator, and to break monopolies.

anchor.surface_text: on the ground that he was companypetent and qualified and satisfied the requirement which the RTA had laid down, that is to say, that a new-comer and a small operator should be introduced on the relevant route and also on the ground that Government should try to break monopolies.

facts.text: Minister rejected appellant's application firstly because appellant not being heir should not prosecute, secondly not new-comer or small operator.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of his order, the Minister rejected the appellants application for permit on two grounds firstly, the appellant number being an heir to Ram Autar Lal Jain, should number have been allowed to prosecute the application before the RTA and, secondly, that the appellant did number satisfy the criterion set up by the RTA in so far as the appellant was neither a new-comer number a small operator.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition to Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant took the matter to the Patna High Court by means of a writ petition.

facts.text: Patna High Court summarily dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition was summarily dismissed by the High Court.

facts.text: There is no provision in Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 for succession to applicant's right to prosecute application for stage carriage permit.

anchor.surface_text: The problem arises because there is numberprovision in the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939, which provides for succession to an applicants right to prosecute his application for a stage carriage permit before the Transport Authorities.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that heirs or legal representatives do not have right to prosecute application after death of applicant before consideration by RTA.

anchor.surface_text: the heirs or legal representatives of the applicant have the right to step into the shoes of the deceased applicant and prosecute the application filed by him before the Regional Transport Authority.
Motor Vehicles Act, 1939, which provides for succession to an applicants right to prosecute his application for a stage carriage permit before the Transport Authorities.

issues.text: whether, upon the death of an applicant for a stage carriage permit before his application has been considered by the Regional Transport Authority, the heirs or legal representatives of the applicant have the right to step into the shoes of the deceased applicant and prosecute the application filed by him before the Regional Transport Authority

anchor.surface_text: The principal question that has arisen for determination in this appeal is whether, upon the death of an applicant for a stage carriage permit before his application has been considered by the Regional Transport Authority, the heirs or legal representatives of the applicant have the right to step into the shoes of the deceased applicant and prosecute the application filed by him before the Regional Transport Authority.

issues.text: whether on the death of an applicant for a stage carriage permit in respect of his transport vehicles the Regional Transport Authority has power to allow the person succeeding to the possession of the vehicles to prosecute the application filed by the deceased applicant

anchor.surface_text: this Court had to answer the question as to whether on the death of an applicant for a stage carriage permit in respect of his transport vehicles the Regional Transport Authority has power to allow the person succeeding to the possession of the vehicles to prosecute the application filed by the deceased applicant.

issues.text: whether Messrs. Ram Autar Lal Jain is, in the eye of law, a new entity separate from both Ram Autar Lal Jain, the deceased applicant, as well as his heirs and legal representatives, and that it could not be the successor or legal representative of the deceased in whom any right to continue any proceeding could vest by succession

anchor.surface_text: It was also contended that Messrs. Ram Autar Lal Jain is, in the eye of law, a new entity separate from both Ram Autar Lal Jain, the deceased applicant, as well as his heirs and legal representatives, and that it could not be the successor or legal representative of the deceased in whom any right to continue any proceeding could vest by succes- sion.

arguments.claim: There is no provision in the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939, which provides for succession to an applicant's right to prosecute his application for a stage carriage permit before the Transport Authorities.

anchor.surface_text: The problem arises because there is numberprovision in the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939, which provides for succession to an applicants right to prosecute his application for a stage carriage permit before the Transport Authorities.

arguments.claim: The Motor Vehicles Act confers a right to make an application under Chapter IV and to have it considered if made timely and properly, but the merits are personal and do not automatically transfer to heirs or successors.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that, although, numberperson is entitled to a permit as a matter of right, the Motor Vehicles Act has conferred upon a person the right to make an application under Chapter IV of the Motor Vehicles Act for any of the four types of permits dealt with in that chapter. A person has also the right to have his application companysidered

arguments.claim: Neither the Motor Vehicles Act nor the rules made thereunder provide for the substitution of heirs to prosecute the application of a deceased claimant for a permit.

anchor.surface_text: Probably it was for this reason that neither the Motor Vehicles Act nor the rules made thereunder provide for the substitution of heirs to prosecute the application of a deceased claimant for a permit. in Dhani Devi v. Sant Bihar Ors.

arguments.claim: Order XXII of the Code of Civil Procedure nor Section 306 of the Indian Succession Act, 1925, have any application to applications for stage carriage permits.

anchor.surface_text: Order XXII of the Code of Civil Procedure nor Section 306 of the Indian Succession Act, 1925, have any application in such a case and also that there is no express provision in the Motor Vehicles Act

arguments.claim: Regional Transport Authority has power under Section 61 to transfer a permit already obtained to the person succeeding to possession of vehicles if holder dies.

anchor.surface_text: Section 61 2  to transfer the permit to the person succeeding to the possession of the vehicles covered by the permit. In the course of the judgment in that case this Court observed there We are inclined to think that in the case of death

arguments.claim: In case of death before final disposal, Regional Transport Authority has power to substitute person succeeding to possession of vehicles and allow prosecution of application.

anchor.surface_text: We are inclined to think that in the case of death of the applicant before the final disposal of his application for the grant of a permit in respect of his vehicles the Regional Transport Authority has power to substitute the person succeeding to the possession of the vehicles in place of the deceased applicant and to allow the successor to prosecute the application.

arguments.claim: Dhani Devi observations do not cover case where deceased applicant is not in possession of any motor vehicles; ratio limited to cases where right to vehicles transfers.

anchor.surface_text: The observations set out above, relied upon by the appellant, do number cover a case where the deceased applicant is number in possession of any motor vehicles. arguments.claim: If legislature intended succession to pending permit applications, it would have provided similarly to Section 61; no such provision exists, so cannot import one.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, Section 61 of the Act deals with cases in which a transfer of the permit held can be applied for. if it was the intention of the legislature to provide for succession to whatever claims an applicant for a permit has even before a permit is granted to him, it would have similarly provided for the situation in the case before us.

holdings.text: the Motor Vehicles Act has conferred upon a person the right to make an application under Chapter IV of the Motor Vehicles Act for any of the four types of permits dealt with in that chapter. A person has also the right to have his application considered by the appropriate authority in accordance with the provisions of the Act so long as he makes an application within the prescribed time and in the prescribed form... an application made for a permit under Chapter IV of the Motor Vehicles Act gives only the right that the merits of the applicant will be considered vis-a-vis other applicants. These merits depend generally upon the peculiar position, capabilities, and qualifications of an applicant which may be either personal

A person has also the right to have his application companysidered by the appropriate authority in accordance with the provisions of the Act so long as he makes an application within the prescribed time and in the prescribed form. holdings.text: The observations set out above, relied upon by the appellant, do not cover a case where the deceased applicant is not in possession of any motor vehicles. The ratio of Dhani Devis case supra was simply this since the right to and possession of the vehicles goes from a deceased holder of a permit or an applicant for its transfer to his heirs, the right to continue an application must also necessarily go to them

anchor.surface_text: The observations set out above, relied upon by the appellant, do number companyer a case where the Dhani Devis case  supra  was simply this since the right to and possession of the vehicles goes from a deceased holder of a permit or an applicant for its transfer to his heirs, the right to companytinue an application must also necessarily go to them. It does number decide what will happen if there is numbermotor vehicle to which a deceased applicants heirs or legal representatives can succeed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent limited to cases involving possession of vehicles

holdings.text: Dhani Devis case supra was one which was specifically covered by Section 61 of the Motor Vehicles Act where the permit actually granted and held for a period specified seems to be treated as an adjunct of the possession of the vehicle. It becomes a kind of property right attached to the business of running a vehicle which is actually serving the public on the road. In such case the right does not remain a mere personal right to apply but is of a transferable character

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, Dhani Devis case  supra  was one which was specifically. companyered by Section 61 of the Motor Vehicles Act where the permit actually granted and held for a period specified seems  1  1969  2  S.C.R. 507. to be treated as an adjunct of the possession of the vehicle. It becomes a kind of property right attached to the business of running a vehicle

holdings.reasoning_summary: Granted permits acquire transferable property character under Section 61, unlike pending applications

holdings.text: Section 61 of the Act deals with cases in which a transfer of the permit held can be applied for. if it was the intention of the legislature to provide for succession to whatever claims an applicant for a permit has even before a permit is granted to him, it would have similarly provided for the situation in the case before us. As there is no such provision, we cannot legislate and import one into the Act

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, Section 61 of the Act deals with cases in which a transfer of the permit held can be applied for. if it was the intention of the legislature to provide for succession to whatever claims an applicant for a permit has even before a permit is granted to him, it would have similarly provided for the situation in the case before us. As there is numbersuch provision, we cannot legislate and import one into the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative silence on pre-grant succession inferred from specific provision for post-grant transfers
